posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com:
Rig welders use a variety of custom beds depending on the job. They typically build their own beds. The engine driven Lincoln in that bed is far from lightweight and is likely decades older than the truck as they're insanely rugged. The horizontal gas cylinder, hose reel etc should also have been clues. The tool boxes are designed to hold just what the rig welder needs so they're often outfitted with custom internal dividers etc.

Different welding and equipment repair tasks benefit from different bodies and beds. Rig welding trucks are not equipment service trucks etc. They don't need "cranes" because pipeline and construction sites have ample lifting equipment and nothing a little truck like that carries can compare to (for example) the pipe laying vehicles available. How do so many of you people not know any of this on a DIY board? It's not exotic. BTW welding outdoors disposes nicely of fume issues so in this respect joke are retarded. Rig welders are compensated for providing their equipment, that truck isn't some bauble. I thought the pajeet trolls on /k/ were the worst tards on 4chan until I saw this thread.

How to build them. Austin Ross has some outstanding welding videos:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rKLl64sjRyc

So you've never worked a 12 or 14 hour day and been an hour ot an hour and a half away from any town or city with a hotel or Airbnb? because I have thousands of times, and being able to haul my camper to a campground or even just on site is quite literally a life saver as i'm falling asleep by the end of the day driving home in the dark.

Prime example is working in parts of Saskatchewan, you are 100% an hour away from an city that has a place to stay in a ton of work locations and pipeline locations, and an hour doesnt sound terrible, but when you actually do the math, you wake up at 4 am, you hit the road around 4:30, arrive to site around 5:30 or 5:45 if you grabbed coffee/breakfast, start work at 6, work 14 hours, its now 8 pm, you have to drive an hour home, its 9 pm, you need to eat, shower and sleep, you get say 6 hours of sleep if your lucky, and do it all again. now dot hat for 21 days straight.

Or, have your camper 15 mins from site.

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26240792

The L15B has poor engine oiling, tiny crankshaft with poor rod to stroke ratios which prevent the engine from wanting to rev. The rods are weak and bend or shatter above 250whp. They also have tiny rod bolts which are smaller than an average 10mm oil pan nut. This causes the bolts to fail under stress lunching the engine. The head bolts are undersized which cause head gasket problems. Everything about the engine is designed to be as cheap as possible and to save money on gas, not make power. The only people who defend them do it because they own a car with one in it.

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26242193
They won't be making that much power for very long. Theres a video on YouTube that shows some differences between L15 parts and other honda engines like K20,D16 etc. The l15 crankshaft is about 2/3rds the size of a d16 crankshaft and has tiny balancers and small journals. The rods are much smaller than a k20 and the rod bolts are 3 sizes smaller. The oil galley grooves on the block mains are small and on the center main all oil pressure comes from a single pinhole. No crank girdle to be found. The oil pump gears apparently shatter with increased power or can score and lose oil pressure. The torque to yield head bolts are of a lower quality metal then the K series ones.

This isn't a case of "new engine bad", the l15b is a cost cutting economy engine Honda threw in its Civic SI to save costs and there aren't alot of safety margins built into it once you exceed stock output.

ahh the 3vz-e, the black sheep of the vz engine family. trd built a 400 hp one for baja or dakar or something. last time i saw it was on ebay, dunno who has it now.
iirc the ball joint thing was a design flaw on all early tacos and 96-04 4runners where the ball joint was constantly trying to get pulled out of its socket, causing earlier and more catastrophic failure compared to the revised design after this period where the ball joint is instead compressed into its socket. aftermarket parts would fail much earlier than the oem parts simply because the oem ones were just so much beefier so they gave more warning time before failing completely. The ball joints would also fail if the securing nut wasn't torqued to spec and in some cases people didn't use the cotter pin. The bolts also weren't reusable; who knows how many DIYers didn't know about this either.

The rumble of a V8 in JGTC!

The sound of a roaring V8 and a distinct yellow figure, a sight that in 2002 was a far more familiar sight in the American Le Mans Series, but in that same year, the Autobacs All Japan GT Series had a similar sighting.

Entered by American car tuner ZIPSPEED, the Dunlop clad C4 was of a different breed to its more known Le Mans focused C5.R counterpart. Driven by Toshiyuki Yamamoto and Izumi Yoshida, the C4 struggled against its more suitable rivals, setting a 1:48.146 in its first qualifying session of 2002, in the All Japan GT Championship at Fuji Speedway and failing to qualify for the race while the polesitting #62 Vemac R&D Sport RD320R achieved a 1:32.379.

Four more races were attempted that year, however success never came the team's way, with the C4 making it to qualifying but never having enough speed to make the race.

posts.com: I need some recs. I recently moved to NE Wyoming from the PNW and holy FUCK the snow and wind here is brutal. I have a 2013 FJ; I added some big KC fogs on the bumper for the rain and fog of the PNW and they helped a ton. However, they don't do much, if at all, for some of the insane snow and white out conditions here. Normally I try to avoid when the weather is this bad, but I got stuck in it twice and visibility was dick. What would be some good, functional lights I could mount to help? I know orange helps in white conditions, but I really don't have much room at all left on my bumper to mount any. I do have spots on top of my roof near my rack where I could easily make two brackets to put two big ones up there. I am new to this, so any help would be appreciated. Not a fan of the shitty Chinese light bar looks and would prefer to stay to two round lights-they go with the retro/round lights already on the FJ and lightbars with little square LEDs look out of place. However, I am pragmatic above all else, so if a light bar would be best I would gladly just do that.

posts.name: BigC

>>26241081
do not mount the lights to the roof if you wanna see shit
they will simply illuminate the fog and blind your worse than no lights at all
you'll be looking through the beam of light
you want the fog lights low, you do not want to be looking through your light beam, you want to be as offset as possible from the lights in order to maximize visibility in fogs
trust me on this, i have roof mounted lights and in the snow or fog they make driving harder, you want bumper mounted lights, lower is better, in fog and snow

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26241325
if you're driving in clear weather, roof mounted is the best however, you will not see shadows cast like when lights are mounted below eye level
with lights below eye level, you can't tell if the shadow ahead is a 1 inch from or a 10 foot drop on a dirt road
in fog however, the roof lights are worse than useless, they will fucking blind you

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26242430
>Where do you get your waste oil and how does fueling work ?
i do oil changes on all my cars and for work and my friends cars, i dump the oil into a clean container then dump that straight into my gas tank, usually it's around 50/50 mix if i blend it first then fill my tank with it, i don't wanna run 80/20 or more until i get a dual tank set up for reliability reasons
also i get oil from a diesel shop where they do semi oil changes
it makes zero difference to the performance of the engine, but if you don't pre filter it you clog fuel filters often, i have had to change fuel filters quite a few times, so i really need to work on better filtering before i dump it in kek
still filters are cheap and diesel is expensive so 2 gallons of diesel is the cost of a new filter
im gonna be buying a WVO centrifuge soon so that should solve all my problems

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26242430
if you know your oil is dry and relatively clean, you can mix it 80/20 with gasoline and let it settle in drums for a while, then leave the sludge at the bottom, then filter that in filter bags and then dump it in
centrifuge is faster and filters better than bags tho, and centrifuge can use an in line heater to help remove water if it's present
centrifuge will filter out stuff so fine the filters would never touch it, it's honestly the end game when it comes to running waste oil and it's best to just avoid all the filtering work if you wanna get serious about it

Yes. There was a short period of time in the late 80s and early 90s where it was approaching mainstream popularity, but it died pretty quickly because the championship started to be dominated by foreign drivers and they started moving away from the Oval roots. IRL broke away to try and avoid the problems CART had, but the competing championships ended up dividing viewership more (with the people who wanted ovals and American drivers all jumping ship to NASCAR which was at its peak of popularity then, and the people who didn’t mind the internationalism just went to F1). Nowadays the only people who care about Indy are midwesterners, and even then it’s really only the Indy 500.

>>26242427
I think I get why the games seem to fall apart, the hierarchal structure of frostbite makes changing one thing very complicated if it's not like a single float value or something. There's no real way to just turn UI elements off and on, everything you want needs to be written down all the way up the ladder.
For example the way the controls work is strange: the game identifies and has separate mappings for different types of controllers but instead of just saying internally "ok button 1 for controller 1 is gas, button 2 is brake, controller 1 is not an Xbox pad so I will use the steering wheel handling rules" they let the game engine figure out specifically what kind of controller you're using and map "concepts" to "actions" then to a generic layout that is pre-set with all the buttons and axes the game should expect to see for each supported controller, It seemingly has no idea what the actual controller axes and buttons are, probably why heat needed g-hub for any wheels to work.

shit is stupid and is a good example of why big game companies and monolithic multipurpose engines were a mistake
all the dumb fucks that could have put a button rebinding menu in NFS are busy rescuing Battlefield

Announcing /ovg/ Sunday Cup - an upcoming (no firm date yet but expect February) series in Assetto Corsa where you pick and choose your own car.

Rules are a little bit complicated for this one so read the wiki: http://wiki.get-good.net/index.php?title=/ovg/_Sunday_Cup but the tl;dr for you is this: Find a car listing in the permitted countries with a car worth at most 2000 euros, and a maximum of 200 bhp. Submit this car to the (temporary) doc below and get it approved for entry. Beware! You may ONLY choose a car noone else has chosen the same body style of, ie. you can have a BMW E92 and a BMW E30 in the series, but no two BMW E92s regardless of type. Read the wiki for in-depth rules.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1vlVjNh8r6o_KYUFHf7Hcp8ZaYS5lsEZwFvTeu_K_c1Q/edit#gid=515811564

>>26243109
12.6 is acceptable resting voltage. Noisy starters are (you hope) just an elderly starter motor. When you remove that inspect the flywheel/flex plate gear teeth with a bright light.

If good, no worries so replace starter. Plenty of info online. Don't omit disconnecting the ground cable at the battery before molesting starter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26243166
Over the tires is most secure because a bounce doesn't loosen straps. Soft slings and tire bridles are not required but worth a look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26242898
If this is a BMW or Audi or similar German car, the batteries have to be coded in. You can't just pull the old battery and put the new battery in.
Assuming you covered that already then:
Have you explored parasitic electricity loss?
Go to the auto parts store and have them test your battery. If the battery looks good then I would suspect something is drawing power while the car is off

>>26242939
I wonder if your transmission mount is going? Mounts for the engine and the transmission and the drivetrain in general are supposed to flex a little to help keep vibration out of the cockpit, but if they deteriorate or are old, they can flex too much and cause lag and wheel jump and all sorts of nonsense.

>>26243135
Newegg used to be pretty much number one for electronic computer parts. Retailing but then it was bought by a Chinese company and has been shit ever since. I avoiding you act like the plague, but back around 2012 it was tits and I bought several things from them.

>>26243166
Springs don't wear out whether they're compressed or extended, they only wear out with use, so if your goal is to preserve the life of your shocks I would tie it down so that it's compressed.

posts.com:
In March 2000, auto sport Magazine of Japan’s front page carried the story that MTCI Racing Team would enter the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM for the upcoming JGTC season, the ultimate “GT1 prototype” racing against the Supras, Skylines, and NSXes. Little is known about the entry apart from Marco Apicella being appointed as the first driver.

However, somewhere along with the negotiations between MTCI and Mercedes-Benz, and perhaps in large part from the shame of the CLR’s massive failure at Le Mans in ‘99, the sale fell through. MTCI Racing Team would instead field a privately-built Porsche Boxster in GT300, with Apicella driving.

By season’s end, MTCI and its race team had collapsed into bankruptcy after the dot-com bubble burst. Chairman Yu Hayakawa was later arrested in 2002 for stock sales fraud. And save for its victory in the 1998 Suzuka 1000km, the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM never raced in Japan

Moslers actually raced in quite a few national-level GT championships like Grand-Am British, Belgian, Spanish, Australian GT series as well as Grand-Am, several SRO series, and a few rounds in FIA GT as an invite until the homologation rules made it so that a small-scale manufacturer could never be eligible for championship points. The car was fast, but also cheap to buy and cheap to run. It's downfall was not being eligible for homologation and just different series nerfing it because of its engine displacement.

The Japanese series would probably see the most of the different variants of the car through the years. It would have the original R, then the GT3 spec, and then the Judd-powered M.

>>26238810
A prototype did compete in 1994. Team Taisan is a stalwart in Japanese motorsports, having formed in 1983 as a privateer team and owned by the Taisan Industrial Company, a global manufacturer of electronic solenoid pumps.

The team enjoyed much racing success throughout the earlier Group A eras with a battery of Nissan R32 GT-Rs, along with BMW M3s in the lower JTCC series.

Business was clearly booming, as the team rocked up to the 1994 season fielding a Ferrari F40 and an ex-Group C Porsche 962 prototype (chassis 962-164). Consider the absurdity: a genuine Le Mans legend rubbing doors with tin-top GT cars. It was an impressive show of force, perfectly encapsulating the excess of Japan’s booming economy and well-heeled motoring enthusiasts. Over five rounds, Taisan’s Porsche 962C and Ferrari F40 won one meeting each, although the championship was ultimately won by Masahiko Kageyama in the Calsonic Hoshino Racing GT-R.

The ‘300ZX-GTS’ in these photos, chassis #009, is a little different than some of the earlier cars. For a start, it’s not twin-turbo V6-powered. Instead, a Nissan VH-series V8 can be found ahead of the quick-change rear end.

Whether it was a spare car or a development car is where things get a little bit murky, but it’s one of only two cars built by Cunningham Racing originally configured for use with the V8 engine, not retrofitted afterwards as other cars were. This would have allowed it to race in the 1995 IMSA GTS-1 class (the VG engine was outlawed at the end of the ’94 season), but the car was reportedly sold to Japan before it competed in any US events In 1997, it had been entered in a couple of JGTC GT500 class races wearing Fedex logos, but did not enjoy any success. Today, in its restored condition, it features the iconic Cunningham Racing 12 Hours of Sebring-winning livery.

The rumble of a V8 in JGTC!

The sound of a roaring V8 and a distinct yellow figure, a sight that in 2002 was a far more familiar sight in the American Le Mans Series, but in that same year, the Autobacs All Japan GT Series had a similar sighting.

Entered by American car tuner ZIPSPEED, the Dunlop clad C4 was of a different breed to its more known Le Mans focused C5.R counterpart. Driven by Toshiyuki Yamamoto and Izumi Yoshida, the C4 struggled against its more suitable rivals, setting a 1:48.146 in its first qualifying session of 2002, in the All Japan GT Championship at Fuji Speedway and failing to qualify for the race while the polesitting #62 Vemac R&D Sport RD320R achieved a 1:32.379.

Four more races were attempted that year, however success never came the team's way, with the C4 making it to qualifying but never having enough speed to make the race.

posts.com:
The JGTC Honda that took on the 24 Hours of Nurburgring!

In 2004, a semi-works Honda programme enlisted a special car to take on the unique challenge that is the Green Hell. The team that year aimed for overall victory and as such acquired a car that could bring them that. That said car was the 2002 GT500 spec Honda NSX. The mid-engine car was already a proven victor in the All Japan Grand Touring Car Championship thanks to the three wins earned by Nakajima Racing, and one each by Mugen and Dome in the 2002 season.

The #3 Honda NSX was entered under the Sport Auto banner and was driven by Armin Hahne, Robert Lechner, Markus Oestreich, and Robin Liddell. A few changes were done to the car to accommodate Nurburgring and the length of the race. One of those changes was the V6 engine being down tuned from the JGTC regulated 500hp to 420hp for reliability. Other changes include endurance lights and Michelin tires of which the car never ran on in the JGTC. The NSX weigh a minimum of 1200kg as par the rules of A6, the class the Honda competed in at Nurburgring.

The #3 Sport Auto NSX had a small amount of kilometres under its belt before contesting the 24 Hours of Nurburgring. Lack of testing however didn't stop the German squad from placing inside the top 15 in qualifying, showing the potential of a JGTC car in uncharted territory. The NSX successfully started the race keeping up with the cars ahead of it which included DTM derived machinery from Audi and Opel. The car however experienced technical problems early in the race and completed 38 laps/7 hours before retiring. https://youtu.be/LRKIAK5Yw3w

>Toyota made history by winning the 2007 Tokashi 24-Hour Race with its Supra HV-R hybrid race car. It is the first time ever that a Hybrid race car has won a competition.

The Supra’s success follows an entry the previous year when Toyota was the first car manufacturer to enter a hybrid vehicle – the Lexus GS450h – into the Tokashi 24-Hour race which finished 17th overall. By entering hybrid systems into racing events, Toyota engineers hope to discover ways to make hybrid systems, most famously fitted to the Toyota Prius production car, more efficient and lighter. In only the second year of competition Toyota used – with success – the data gained from last year’s race in order to develop a new, special racing unit to the limits of hybrid performance.

The race car was based on the iconic Supra GT used in Super GT races in Japan. It was modified and equipped with a special racing hybrid system. In order to improve the system’s energy regeneration and operating efficiency during the race, the following two distinctive technologies have been incorporated into it:

A four-wheel energy regeneration and drive system has been adopted which includes in-wheel motors in the front wheels in addition to one 150 kW rear-axle mounted electric motor. Thanks to this energy regeneration system with three motors/generators, the vehicle can more efficiently recover a greater amount of energy during rapid deceleration and braking from high speeds.

In light of the fact that racing involves a repeated acceleration and deceleration under full system performance, a quick-charging capacitor system was adopted instead of the usual rechargeable batteries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Every modern McLaren, from the 2011 MP4-12C to the P1 to the 720S is powered by a single family of twin turbo V8s. This engine didn’t come out of nowhere; it started life in a largely-forgotten supercar from Nissan.

This is the Nissan VRH35L. It’s a twin-turbo 3.5 liter aluminum V8 used for endurance racing at Le Mans, the final line of development of Nissan’s VRH35 architecture that debuted in ‘89. Nissan and Tom Walkinshaw Racing (TWR) put the VRH35L together for their entry into the madcap GT1 category back in 1997 in the R390 GT1.

Engine weight was 170 kilos (just over 374 pounds), which I assume counts the weight of the two IHI turbos. Nissan claims its torque figure was “over” 520 lb-ft and horsepower was somewhere around 640 in race trim, 550 for the street-legal homologation specials mandated by the rules.

I do mean specials; only one street R390 GT1 got built, rebodied and VIN-swapped from red to blue, which never made it out of Nissan’s hands.

Nissan was never quite able to eke out a win at Le Mans with the R390 GT1, much as it had never quite been able to get an overall victory in its thousand-horsepower Group C years.

After running in 1997, 1998 and 1999, Nissan peaced out of the 24 Hours of Le Mans’ top classes and the whole effort has fallen into a dusty part of history in a way that, say, Porsche’s 1990s campaigns did not.

But the engine lives on still! Early on in the development of the old MP4-12C, McLaren picked out the VRH35 for the basis of its engine program and bought the rights to it from TWR, as Car and Driver reported at the time. McLaren and their engine builder Ricardo did a great deal of work to the design and basically made the thing their own, renaming it the M838T.

yeah. took a day or two to nail the basics down. lots of stalling at lights and waving to the driver behind me kek. At one point while learning I was starting to regret swapping to a manual because I kept feeling like shit holding up everyone behind me.
one bro in a hilux must've put two and two together because he waved back three times in a sort of 'it's cool mate shit happens'
But there was no way I was going to put the auto back lol so I just kept at it. Once i realised i could increase the margin before the engine stalled by just keeping the revs at 1500-2000 rpm and slowly releasing the clutch at the same time, i think that was the moment where another anon in a recent thread described learning to drive manual as
>you keep practising until one day it randomly clicks and you never unlearn how to drive a manual ever again
i did about 2000 km in the past week or so just driving everywhere and nowhere and having an absolute blast. People kept telling me that manuals will suck in stop start traffic but honestly I didn't find it too bad. Just figure out the pace at which you can just crawl along.
Now it's a matter of refining the technique. Have gotten better and better at revmatching, but it'll be a while yet until i can do the manual racing memes like heel toe shifting and all that
pic related was when I initially installed the pedals. looked wonky as you can see, thankfully my work had a hydraulic metal bender which allowed me to get the pedals at the perfect position

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26244581
How much do you charge for a battery replacement?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26244595
They pretty much never need replaced, only refurbished or balanced. You take the battery out, put it on a table, and there's 28 individual modules inside you can service and replace. It's not a single unit like a smartphone battery

Hell my current daily is an early gen 2 Prius I picked up for free because the owner was going to send it to the scrapyard due to a dead hybrid battery. Got it home, scanned the battery via OBD2 and my phone, figured out which cells were bad, swapped them out, and I've put 6k miles on it in the last month. Cost me ~$45 for the modules and I have a converted PC power supply to charge new cells to spec.

If for some reason you decide you want a new battery pack, it costs around 2k from the Toyota dealer, although I actually recommend going aftermarket and getting lithium cells for around the same price, gives you more power and better fuel economy and stays in EV mode longer

>>26237901
+1 on Everstarts.

There’s only a couple OEMs that make all of those batteries for the parts stores and big box retailers. I have used them all in the fleet of cars I’m always taking care of. They all last like +/-3mos of the warranty period, could be a Duralast Gold or DieHard or Everstart.

Everstarts at Walmart are always like 30% cheaper than the auto parts stores. Like the Gold (4yrs?) at Walmart is the same price as the standard (3yr) at the auto parts stores. Plus the Everstart 3 year warranty is a real 3 year warranty. Some of the parts stores like AutoZone prorate the last year, so Duralast 3 year warranty batteries are really only 2 year free replacement. If a $160 Duralast 3yr dies at 2 years 9 months, they will give you $40 towards the new battery. It pissed me off so much the one time I called to see if a dead battery was still under warranty, guy on the phone told me it was, but it was only like 2 months left and I got $25 towards the new one, it would’ve been cheaper to go to Walmart where the battery was like $40 cheaper.

Also Walmart has easy returns. They will go by the sticker on the battery if you don’t have a receipt, and most of the time they don’t even test it. I’ve heard lots of stories of AutoZone dudes wanting to put it on a charger overnight and dragging ass to replace batteries under warranty.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26238910
Where did you get it tested? The kids at the auto parts stores can be retarded.

But you could have a bad starter or a bad connection anywhere between the starter and battery as well. Time to break out the multimeter. The annoying thing is you’re not really going to be able to test resistance easily because resistance with a couple mA like the meter reads is different than starting the car with hundreds of amps. Maybe you can probe some different spots along the circuit while cranking the starter? I’m sure some Youtube genius knows more than me.

Either way you should have a multimeter. See what kind of voltage you get at the battery as you’re cranking the engine. HF also has 100A carbon pile load testers for cheap, and Amazon has the new Chinese digital ones for $25-$50, but a multimeter will test more than just the battery.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26242922
Might still be under warranty. Depending on your driving style, climate, and what grade of battery you got, 2-5 years is the general lifespan.

Load test it. The auto parts stores will do it too. That’s how you can tell if it’s on its way out. There are battery testers if you want to buy one too, or get yourself a multimeter and learn how to use it. The voltage of the battery is one thing, but a dying battery can still have good voltage when it’s just sitting there. But once you start cranking the starter, a good battery shouldn’t drop much more than 10V, a dead battery won’t start the car, and a dying battery will get like <9V when cranking the starter.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26243421
It might just need a charge and a long drive. Lack of driving plus cold weather will lead to a low state of charge. But sounds like it’s on the edge. Lead acid batteries like being topped off all the time, so if you don’t drive much and your commutes are short, it’s not getting back up to 100% charge and will die faster than one in a car that takes more frequent long drives.

If you have a multimeter, look up how to test the battery and find a voltage drop test. Make sure the battery is somewhat charged like run the car for awhile the day or morning before, then all you need to do is measure the voltage as you’re starting the car and see how low it drops with the starter going. That will tell you a lot about the health.

My issue with subaru after 2019 is their use of the massive tablet infotainment especially as they hide many controls behind that computer. This is exactly the opposite of their previous gens which had screens but all of the controls were still physical and the screen only controlled media stuff. My second issue is with the CVT. While Subaru has made strides in improving their CVT reliability my big issues have always been the inconsistent power delivery in questionable conditions. The CVT computer or computer systems as a whole are known to refuse to transmit power purely to prevent a high load from being transferred through the CVT. It'll either use TCS to reduce throttle or the TCU will disengage the torque converter. The engine will rev incessantly but none of that power makes it to the wheels.

At 38k USD thats a lot of money for the cheapest XT. Thats basically top trim for most other economy car makers. I would still prefer other cars like the Rav4 hybrid because its AWD system is just as good for any realistic scenario and it gets a fuck ton better gas mileage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I lost my dad to cancer in September of 2020 and lost my mom to the same in october of 2020. I doubt your parent's will pass within weeks like mine did, but I believe that my point is still salient. You probably do not want to be around day in and day out at the end. I moved out at 18, grad school at 22, bought a house, got married, had a daughter etc etc... typical american dream shit. When my mom and dad got really sick I ended up spending an enormous amount of time at their house because the writing was on the wall and I wanted to get in as much time as I could. As noble as that sounds, the experience was truly scarring. My dad had brain cancer my mom bone cancer (stemming from breast cancer or so the doctors believed) , and seeing a once proud man that cold shrug off a broken bone not be able to feed himself and watching my loving, caring mom lash out at me in ways that would never have happened in the past because she was panicked abut dying has fucked me up for the rest of my life. Luckily, I'm 38 and as I said, have my own family that I can focus on. I probably wouldn't even change anything if given the opportunity, and if this weren't an anonymous board, I'd probably not even bring it up, but from someone that's lived it...you're going to want some space when that happens.

Tesla Model 3 is a definite future classic. I predict something of a curve like what was seen with the classic Beetle.

Tons of them on the road, so initially they won't be seen as rare desirable classic cars. They'll be seen as cheap common vehicles.
In the late 30s and into the 40s Enthusiasts will start buying cheap older examples with 70% degraded battery packs, swap in cheap 300kg 200kWh packs that can sustain 400kW output, replace the motor controller hardware and turn them into monsters.
Or they'll buy up Model 3s that aren't really running anymore and use them as donor cars for kit builds. Something that has already started, but will really pick up once there are kits based on using Model 3 running gear.

Both of which will reduce the supply, and ultimately drive the prices back up to the point where higher-end EVs may actually be easier to source and pristine unmodified examples that nostalgic Zoomers want will go for a lot of money.

This isn't true. Not every state refers to common law to solve issues or create precedent. Many laws are written and passed without the input of courts. Not in the 17th century sense, no. But all statute laws in the US still have to pass through courts to be deemed constitutional and thus lawful. Laws get overturned by the courts all the time. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26243963
>no they don’t
Not formally, as in no they don’t have a court case over every single law. Because it’s generally assumed that when a law is passed it’s constitutional because actually taking every new law to court would be a waste of time and resources. But ANY law can be challenged in court, where it is thus forced to be judged.
The origin of the constitution is in common law, specifically descending from about 800 years of precedent from rulings based on the Magna Carta. It's a codification of common law rulings so ancient and sacred so as to be deemed foundational for anglo society and thus above future debate.

>every EU country has its own constitution
I know. But parliamentary supremacy means those constitutions are mere suggestions, rather than hard rules. It’s expected that politicians will follow them, but there are no machinations to resolve issues if politicians choose not to. This comes from how, as european nations became republics and tried to follow the US model, they fundamentally misunderstood the roles of government and the rule of law. In the US, it was decided that the King would be replaced by the constitution, with parliament (congress) subservient to it. >>26240493
>How do you determine a budget?
I think it comes down to a few things with varying priorities over others
>whats your take home pay?
>how much money do you have after all your post-tax bills are paid?
>how much savings do you have?
>do you intend on financing?
If someone had 10k in cash, a stable income, a reasonable amount of savings, then theres no reason why they couldn't put 10k down on a 20k car and have a small 10k loan that would come out to say 150 a month.

But you have any serious deficits in your financial well being then you can toss out a lot of these freedoms. If you have low wages or you don't have much money after your bills or you don't have much in savings, maybe your credit isn't that great.

>Yea I may have 50k saved, but that doesnt mean I should spend 50k or even 20k.
Absolutely correct, you may be more frivolous than others or more frugal. Maybe you create a budget for yourself in that you intend on spending 20k on a car and you have to reasonably justify how you allocate money. Maybe you're more frugal and think spending 20k of your 50k savings is unreasonable.

Its hard to look at this objectively and create a strict metric as to what it means to be able to afford something and be unable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26240044
The rally is an off-road endurance event. The terrain that the competitors traverse is much tougher than that used in conventional rallying, and the vehicles used are typically true off-road vehicles and motorcycles, rather than modified on-road vehicles. Most of the competitive special sections are off-road, crossing dunes, mud, camel grass, rocks, and erg among others. The distances of each stage covered vary from short distances up to 800–900 kilometres (500–560 mi) per day. "Amateurs" typically struggle with the event. The rough terrain and lack of skill usually results in accidents and serious injuries.

The Dakar rally features a much greater variety of vehicles than traditional rally's, including bikes, quads, and trucks. Dominant manufacturers within the Dakar Rally are KTM for bikes, Yamaha for quads and Kamaz in trucks. Out of the big three Kamaz are most notable as they have won using the largest variety of vehicles instead of sticking with a select few models. In 2006 a tracked vehicle category was proposed and rejected due to the necessary volume of sub-divisions to ensure fair competition. In 2018 an EV category was proposed, this to was rejected as "there currently exists no electric vehicle capable of crossing the most remote stages of the Dakar unsupported and it would place an unnecessary risk on support crews to enable them to do so", despite annual reviews and counter-claims this continues to be the case. In 2020 Volkswagen proposed an all-electric entry for the 2021 race and although accepted as a non-competing entry, failed to appear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
130k mi 2013 Honda Fit owner here

Valve adjustment is the biggest one you should do. Finding a place that does this is a pain because most places say it's not needed but on the Fit it is. This will improve your fuel economy and make your engine feel a little newer.
While you do that you should do the spark plugs at the same time. Make sure you go with the NGK laser iridium spark plugs so you can go another 100k miles on them.
Serpentine belt you can look at from the engine bay and most likely won't need to replace it unless yours looks really worn.
Drain and fill your tranny don't do a flush. A flush will fuck up your transmission by blasting it with too much pressure. To change 95% of your transmission fluid drain and fill it 3 separate times over the course of a week. You can easily do this at home. Use only "Genuine Honda ATF fluid" not shit you buy from vatozone.
Other things misc things: replace your cabin air filter that's behind your glove box. Open your glove box and push the hinges inward that exposes the box your cabin air filter is in. Replace it with some paper filter you can buy at vatozone.
Keep up with your oil changes and replace your engine air filter every so often. That should take you to another 100,000 miles at least.

drain and replace is good, but you need to do this several times as this wont get all the fluid in one go

Definitely check it out. The bolt has a 65KWH battery and the EV gets 259 miles (EUV slightly worse at 247). If you're getting 21 mpg that means you would have to buy 12 and a third gallons of gas to go 259 miles. Now you have to look up your electrical prices for off peak times. My off peak rate is about 8 cents per KWH and they have a special plan for EV drivers that lowers it down to about 6 cents per KWH. At 8 cents/KWH that comes out to $5.20 to go 259 miles. With current gas prices near me at 3.20 a gallon that comes out to be $39.46 to drive the same amount in your car. That is over 7.5 times cheaper. You said you spend 6k in fuel each year so you would be saving over 5k per year in fuel costs if you have similar electricity rates.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. The OP's picture is from 2021 in Amelia Island, Florida where three Divan curators took their pieces of garbage to an airstrip to drag race at a blistering 50mph for a hundred dollar grand prize. The airport was well aware of the stunt and endorsed it.

Because it's funny.

posts.name: s10fag

>>26239093
yeah i never changed mine because it got 26mpg highway with the 6, everyone was telling me i wouldn't be happy without 3.08's or 3.27's

if you have an egr there's a specific way to set it up, otherwise it will bog straight off idle, most people delete it and since you have a 351 it might not even be much benefit

i was happy *enough* after i swapped to a clutch fan, de-catted, and recurved my distributor, but i ended up never upgrading my carb because the goofy intake on my car

duraspark is quite a pain to recurve and most pre-smog distributors have a decent curve for stock stuff, a pertronix would be good if you had points but it isnt that huge of an upgrade

ford heads are typically restricted on the exhaust port if you were willing to do a little more work, but intake, exhaust, and the other little things should give you a nice boost

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
VAN TREASURE HUNT UPDATE:
This sort of applies as a classic, even though this thing was manufactured in 1992 Brazil. It's a VW Kombi camper van, manufactured exactly as it had been for over 30 years at that point, except with a modern engine for its day. No EFI, straight carburation. If it doesn't apply here, then I'll shut up about it here and not speak on it again. But I think most of us understand that Central and South American car culture persisted in continuing manufacturing aftermarket designs long after the original production run.

Over in Houston, GF and I came across a remarkable deal and made friends of the sellers, as they were prioritizing their home repairs over the dream car. Runs and drives, and because they liked us, are giving us an incredible discount (From 7k -> 6k without even attempting to haggle). The only major rust spots are in the front captain seats - everything else is remarkably good shape. They were inviting us out to dinner as we were getting ready to leave, so absolutely made a great impression. Incredible energy and vibes coming from the young couple, so I made a DIY friend in the process. Absolutely stellar. I told them we'd have to think about the purchase itself; but when my woman sat in the driver's seat, she immediately felt completely at home. So now more than ever, she's ready to commit to this hobby even if we hadn't handed over a check yet.

pre smog cams are pretty decent

there's not much to gain unless you increase the powerband or narrow your LSA

to narrow your LSA and make decent gains you would need some substantual exhaust work ie longtubes & port match

substantial increase in powerband or LSA you would need a higher stall converter and maybe a regear

if you do a cam take note that a lot of replacement cam gears are inherently 4 degrees retarded as this is what ford did after 1972

>>26239690
I said avoid edelbrock.
They're garbage.
>To adjust float level on an Edelbrock, turn the top upside down and measure the distance from the tip of the float to the air horn gasket; it should be 7/16-inch. If adjustments are necessary, carefully bend the arm on the float with needle nose pliers.
That way is shit and never guarantees the fuel level is correct, which affects fuel delivery through the carb.
Whereas on a holley the needle and seat are screw-in and there's a weep hole on the side of the float bowl.
Remove weep hole plug and screw the need and seat up or down until fuel level is at the weep hole.

>>26243733
That depends entirely on where you're located and what body style you like.
I chose a Ford Pinto because it's hilarious. That, and, it's an excellent entry level vehicle made simple in automotive respects, ease of customizing in mind. That, and I really enjoy the scavenger hunt for parts in scrapyards.

What's your fancy? Pre-war? Midcentury? Malaise muscle?
You have to pick what you like, and then run with it and run hard. What tools do you have at your disposal, and how much work do you plan on doing? Pick an interesting and underutilized vehicle if you want to buy really low, but expect the search to be hard. If you want something easier to find parts for, go for something more well known.

Remember, you will get what you pay for in your initial buy-in, unless you're lucky. If you buy extra low, expect extra low grade stuff.

posts.com:
200 mph is 200 mph. If you're going to crash at 200 mph, your only chance of surviving is if the car stays on the ground/vectors the impact into something below it's center of gravity or if it rolls enough times to slowly dissipate the energy. 200 mph and 3 straight rolls due to turbulence is gonna kill you unless the chassis is designed like an airplane with a fully molded safety cage/crumple zone built into it, not just welded on.

i've got the 1.9 JTDm version, had it for 1.5 years now, so far the only real problems is the shitty m32 transmission whining, but from what i've read and heard, thats where it basically stops(fuck you opel), rust on the front and rear subframe and rust on the rear suspension components, one of my front springs just snapped out of nowhere while it was parked for 2 weeks(i have the Ti trim so the sport springs are kinda pricey), the rubber pipe after the intercooler broke, and theres kinda a bit of oil at the turbo and right after it, If you cant stand bumps on the road i'd go for the normal trims since they are way softer than the Ti, but other than that i dont think i've had any super serious issues with it so far, its actually been pretty reliable.

If you want to buy one just dont go with a JTS engine, they are horrible, shit power and shit reliability, especially the 3.2 V6 that has 20L/100km fuel consumption...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226818
Oh and forgot to mention, if they work on the mk1 they should also work all the way up to the mk2 GT, the RS gets bigger discs and different 57mm calipers, from the Laguna I believe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Crossovers and EVs currently.
Full size body-on-frame SUVs with traditional longitudinal drivetrain have a purpose. Towing or plowing with a short wheelbase. Same with mid-size SUVs with the traditional longitudinal drivetrain for rough terrain and light towing. I am not a fan of rollover prone designs. Death traps are to be scrapped.
SUVs like the Escape, Equinox, MDX, Murano and Tucson are glorified AWD versions of FWD car drivetrains. Crossovers are soullessly designed. Many crossovers are garbage piles with plenty of failures and terrible to work on. Unibody full size SUVs share similar failures and repair difficulty. EVs require a reliance on Chinese lithium and chips, so they are not good for humanity. I am looking forward to golf cart level technology that can allow for easy diagnosis and repair. I don't want to be at the mercy of a touch screen going out and glitching or communist spyware. I've heard one too many stories of vehicles locking then catching on fire. I don't want Chinesium in my vehicle. Anything from there is problems.
What happened to NiMH technology no one talks about improving on? I heard a few big companies hold the patent and do not let anyone do anything with the technology.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26236529
>implying electric vehicle charging is in anyway wide spread, convenient or fast.
Yes it is. At least if you own a Tesla like I do. Could the charging network in the Midwest be better? Sure. But at least it exists, and 250kW charging stations have really rolled out in the last few years.
The only reason to really use the nav anymore for trip planning, is that when it knows you're going to a fast charger it can precondition the battery so that it will charge as fast as possible and let you know when there's enough to continue the trip.

CCS cars probably do still need to do a bit more planning, but that's why a PHEV would be nice to have. Honda should just build a sporty car with a battery for daily range and peak performance and a little 660cc range extender motor.

By contrast Hydrogen fueling stations in the US only exist in California, and unless the only place out of California you want to go is Reno you're not going to have a very good time.

>>26237207
Not even all gas cars are good for long trips, especially not in places without infrastructure to support them.
EV infrastructure is getting pretty good in the US especially if you have a long range car with about 75kWh or more, and the ability to use both NACS and CCS.

Its not like gas stations instantly appeared everywhere the minute ICE cars were invented in the 1880s. It took decades for the status quo we enjoy now to emerge. Infrastructure for long recreational road trips in gas cars didn't really exist in North America till the 1950s 40 years after the first cars for the masses started appearing.
Affordable long range BEVs for the masses only really hit the market about 5 years ago, and they're already capable of long road trips if you want to use them that way.

If you can have one car, and you own a home. Buy a PHEV.
If you can have two cars, buy a short range BEV for daily use and whatever weekend vehicle you like.
If you don't own a home, buy a HEV.

If you're an enthusiast and you have the money, there's really no reason not to have a long range BEV as your daily car.

>>26242496
>that completely ignores that the expenditures to expand the electrical system to handle increased loads
No it doesn't. Building out Nuclear reactors to meet increased demand is something that will happen even without switching to BEVs because population and demand by the population for energy is always increasing. Actually if we stop spending 6kWh to produce a gallon of gasoline, and start driving BEVs that do 5 miles a kWh or better total demand on the grid from transportation may actually decrease.

>Compare that to hydrocarbons where most of the hydrogen would be sourced,
No. The Hydrogen economy is all about unchaining from fossil fuels. Fossil sourced Hydrogen is also the equivalent of $15 a gallon, and has no way to lower that since it is both intensive on a limited resource, and requires significant energy.
If you want hydrogen to happen, as an affordable alternative to fast charging Battery Electric cars, then Hydrogen needs to hit about $8 a kg. Something which can only happen with electrolysis from nuclear power or other zero carbon sources.

Hydrogen as a competitive fuel for Internal Combustion is simply never going to happen. Even if all the subsidies were removed from Fossil Fuels tomorrow, Hydrogen would still have a tough time competing because the electric vehicle infrastructure is already mature, and PHEVs can do all their daily driving on cheap electricity and only need to buy expensive fuel for trips.
The only possible economic viability for hydrogen comes as a range extending solution for FCEVs with large enough batteries to not need to drive on hydrogen daily like PHEVs do today, but nobody has mass produced a car like that yet and that will still require a massive investment in hydrogen infrastructure that simply has not happened, and shows no sign of happening.

Hydrogen cars so far seem to just be a zero investment greenwashing campaign that in a decade have gone nowhere. Other than maybe Reno.

>>26243256
All risk assessments are inherently made with incomplete information and are swayed by personal bias. Only you can decide whether the benefit is worth the risk, but also consider that there's a lot that you can do to mitigate both the likelihood and severity of those risks.
The best thing you can do is to increase the amount of information that you have about those risks, like for example knowing that half of all motorcycle crashes are single-vehicle (i.e. with no car involved). You can also learn the kind of hazards that motorcycles typically encounter, and the ways to identify them when they arise. For example, if there's a long shadow in front of you, the sun is directly behind you. That means that drivers in front of you can't see you, even though you have perfect visibility.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also, just for Europeans: given the immense demand for drivers, and the shittiness of most trucking company managers, licensing is usually more of a suggestion than a hard requirement. Most trucking companies don't even see or know the customer, they just move from terminal to terminal with all the loads handled by a third party broker run out of some guy's basement. So long as the load isn't hazmat or overweight, 99% of trailers aren't, the goal is to pick it up from yard A and drop it at yard B. LTLs or the customer itself does the last mile work, either by picking up the trailer themselves or having it crossdocked into one of theirs. LTLs and similar fleets are extremely pissy over who they hire because of this, as they have to interact with customers and do customer service. Even if the "customer service" is just not putting 20 pallets of ice cream in the parking lot expecting the cashiers to deal with it.

This is different across states, liberal states are full of Unions, Teamsters and other Communists that force things like hard licensing requirements, ID checks at weigh stations, safety, and periodic drug testing. Most companies don't bother. Most companies don't even bother with paper checks or direct deposit anymore, they just pay using a comdata card, venmo or western union. There's different flavors and all of them combine on the highway.

And despite hot it looks this actually doesn't block flow as much as you think. When you have a restriction, pressure usually jumps behind it to maintain flow. The restriction has to be so great it overpowers the oil pump. Your oil filter is a bigger restriction to oil flow than a few pieces of RTV.
This was noted in the Savagegeese video looking at the GR86, after about 3,000 track miles the car had a similar looking oil pickup but all the oil pressure was the same meaning there wasn't a real restriction.

It's because they got tired of retards (probably like the people ITT) scrambling to the dealership flipping out because the needle read higher during Summer than it did the previous Winter and "something must be wrong!". I can't tell you how many stupid Boomers on C5 FB groups flip out over their coolant temp readings and do shit they SHOULDN'T do like replace the thermostat with a lower temp version which fucks with the tolerances and actually *does* harm the car. In most cases, they just need to clean out the shit out of their 20 year old radiator, but they run around like a chicken with their head cut off instead.

If they only had a red temp warning light when it actually goes above spec, all of this would be avoided. You really don't need these gauges unless you have a heavily modified race car and actually know enough about everything to know what acceptable temps are and aren't. Putting them in a modern car is at best a LARP and at worst an invitation for retards to second guess literally everything and flip out over nothing. Don't even get me started on the panic people have when the oil pressure gauge fails (super common).

>>26241827
>>26242832
Retard takes. 1-2 minutes of idle warm up (maybe 5 minutes max if it's below freezing) then 50% revs and 50% throttle should be your limit until you reach standard coolant temp. By then, your oil, while cooler than coolant, will be warm enough to be to its correct viscosity (110F is what the local V8 tuner told me was the minimum "send it" temp for oil, which occurs basically right when my car hits the minimum "normal" coolant temp). Too much idling will clog everything up, and naturally slamming the throttle and revving out will blow your engine if you do it enough on a cold engine, esp. a performance engine. Warm everything up gently and allow everything to heat uniformly and then send it.

>>26229087
I work for a large sheriff's department in a very large, rich, liberal county. The county government wants to switch all county vehicles to electric - including police vehicles.

They have been flirting with the F-150 Lightning - however the battery issues and charging logistics are a major obstacle for them to be issued as patrol vehicles.

We use mainly 17-22 Explorers now for patrol, with a few Tahoes and F-150s out there. In rural districts refueling is already an issue with the amount of driving you do between calls. Add in a pursuit or a high speed code run, you are burning through extraordinary amounts of fuel.

We have to be able to refuel quickly - we can't have an EV where the refueling isn't instant. Plus, how are they going to factor in people charging the EVs at home? Are they going to pay a portion of peoples power bills, install charging stations at everyone's homes? etc.

This questions need to be answered. Right now maybe detectives and admin will get EVs. I can't see patrol cops getting them en masse.

posts.com:
>>26239441
you're confusing fun and prettiness with the fact, that back when they were new, getting a car was a huge achievement.
From a mechanical standpoint, they're alright. However, they were designed to 60's spec all the way up to like 2012 when 07 was finally "discontinued". So if you think that doing a full-overhaul every 100k and random issues from new are alright, then yes, they are reliable.
Body-wise they're absolute junk, the metal used after the Fiat stock got used up went to shit, it'd literally rust under it's paint from new. No panel ever fits the same and general measuring tolerance is usually within 2cm(which if you're familiar with soviets in general, is probably old news).

They have massive novelty value, but from a comparison-on-paper standpoint, they're terrible.
It's been already mentioned ITT, but yes, there's a reason why they were replaced with foreign cars almost the moment they were available, even leaving aside the fact that "I got it because it's foreign so I'm better than my neighbor".

tl;dr they're shit, but they have almost infinite cultural value to the people who grew up with them
